name: MichaelKitces
tweet: @scottsalaske @Mike_Thrasher More generally, client leads and lead generation is hugely valuable. Far more so than "just" what Schwab makes on the underlying. VC firms are investing into startups to do this. Schwab already "has" it. I can't blame them for charging (separately) for it. It's valuable.

name: MichaelKitces
tweet: @scottsalaske @Mike_Thrasher If they didn't charge a referral fee, they would have an undue incentive to stop referring altogether and just take the clients internally with their own Schwab Private Client and growing wealth management offering.   For better or worse, this roughly 'equalizes' the field.

tweet: Livestream with @jdcarlson401k @retireholics starting up shortly! The intersection of Financial Planning Nerds and 401(k) Geeks? :)

name: MichaelKitces
tweet: @TomCondron We're not planning to cover it in this #AdvisorTech study. We're only focusing on the tech for individual financial advice offerings.   Nothing against 401(k) plan tech, but that's a whole other world (and a somewhat different sampling process to get data).

name: MichaelKitces
tweet: @scottsalaske That's the point. It's NOT standardized as a %age of the advisor fee. They got rid of that a long time ago, so there would be no incentive to refer higher-fee advisors over others. It's a set amount of basis points regardless of the advisor's fee happens to be.

tweet: @edwinmchoi @Rick_Ferri Yes, eventually they changed it from a percentage of the RIA's revenue, to a flat bps charge (so it's uniform regardless of the RIA's fee schedule and Schwab could be more objective - simply up to the RIA whether they wanted to pay the solicitor fee that Schwab charges).
